final_answer.precision_note: Concentration to 3 s.f., limited by 0.150 mol dm-3 and 23.40 cm3 (3 s.f.).

method: Calculate moles of NaOH used: convert volume to dm3, V(NaOH) = 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Then n(NaOH) = c×V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × 0.02340 dm3 = 0.00351 mol. Use the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O: 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: V(H2SO4) = 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Finally c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Because 2 mol NaOH react per 1 mol H2SO4, the acid concentration should be about half the base concentration when similar volumes are used.
Here base volume (23.40 cm3) is slightly smaller than acid volume (25.00 cm3), so acid concentration slightly less than 0.150/2 = 0.075 mol dm-3; 0.0702 fits.
